newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Iraq oil-for-food plan to get new UN administrators.
newsitem.headline: Iraq oil-for-food plan to get new UN administrators.

text.p: The Iraqi oil-for-food plan will be moved to a new U.N. department shortly, according to a U.N. reform plan announced by U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Wednesday.

Currently, the programme is administered by the Department of Humanitarian Affairs, which will be abolished and replaced by a smaller humanitarian coordinating office that will no longer have operational duties.
U.N. officials expect the Department of Political Affairs, headed by Briton Kieren Prendergast, to take over the functions for the Iraqi programme in the near future. But a date has not been set.

The oil-for-food programme allows Iraq to sell $2 billion of oil over six months in order to buy humanitarian supplies for its people suffering under sanctions imposed when Baghdad's troops invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
The United Nations has put a more than 100 monitors into Iraq to help supervise oil flows and the equitable distribution of food, medicine and other goods.
